datafield.subfield: (authorized access point: Richard, Jérôme (1720?-18..); born 1720? Dijon; language: French; translated from Ancient Greek; chanoine de Vézelay; scholar; member of the Institut de France, section zoology, elected in 1795 [perhaps confusion with L.C. Richard, a member of the Institut, section zoology; see Dictionnaire des journalistes]; form of name in BN Cat. gén.: Richard (Abbé Jérôme))

("Richard (Jérémie). De Dijon, chanoine de Vézelay"; list of works includes L'humanité ... par un aveugle Tartare, 1761, of which authorship is disputed, and Voyages chez les peuples sauvages, 1801)

(Richard (abbé Jérôme), born Dijon approximately 1720, canon of Vézelay; after a long voyage in Italy, settled in Paris approximately 1766; member of the Institut de France, section zoology [perhaps confusion with L.C. Richard, a member of the Institut, section zoology; see Dictionnaire des journalistes]; list of works as in Cioranescu, except omits L'humanité)
(Richard, Jérôme; male; died approximately 1800; clergyman, scholar)
(Richard, Jérôme; died approximately 1800; born in Dijon. died in Paris; priest, scholar)
(authorized access point: Richard, M. F. (1719-1799); source: Voyages chez les peuples sauvages, 1808)
Voyages chez les peuples sauvages, 1801, via HathiTrust, Jan. 29, 2014:
title page (d'après des mémoires du cit. R***)
Voyages chez les peuples sauvages, seconde édition, 1808, via HathiTrust, Jan. 29, 2014:
v. 4, col. 1096 (Voyages chez les peuples sauvages, 1801, is by "Jérôme Richard, chanoine de Vézelay")
Dictionnaire des journalistes, via WWW, Jan. 27, 2014

(Jérôme Richard (?-1800); do not confuse with Jérémie Richard (Cioranescu 18) nor with the zoologist Louis Claude Richard; born Dijon, died Paris approximately 1800; priest in Dijon, then chaplain in Chanceaux and canon of the chapter of Vézelay; member of the Académie de Dijon, June 12, 1750; secretary of the Academy, 1753-1763; tutor of the son of Bourbonne, a judge of the Parlement de Dijon; traveled with his pupil to Italy; involvement in a scandal in 1763 interrupted his career and he retired to the country; list of works as in Cioranescu, except omits L'humanité)
Grimm, F. M. La correspondance littéraire 1er janvier-15 juin 1761, edited and annotated by Ulva Kölving, 1978:

v. 1, page 86 (in Grimm's report dated May 1, 1763, the play "L'humanité ... par un aveugle Tartare" is ascribed to "un certain M. l'abbé Richard") v. 2, pages 136-137 (Kölving notes that this attribution is confirmed by Heméry's journal for April 16, 1763, giving the author as "l'abbé Richard, précepteur des enfants de Pierre-Daniel Bourré, baron de Corberon," a judge of the Parlement de Paris. Richard is not further identified with certainty; possibly Jérôme Richard, born in Dijon approximately 1720, canon of Vézelay and member of the Académie de Dijon since 1750, but he is not known to have resided in Paris)

(authorized access points: Richard, Jérôme: Library Network of Western Switzerland; Richard, Jérôme, 1770 fl.: National Library of the Netherlands; Richard, Jérôme -1800: German National Library; Richard, M. F., 1719-1799: NUKAT Center of Warsaw University Library, Sudoc, France; Richard, Jérôme 1720?-18..: National Library of France; Richard, M. l'abbé (Jérôme): LC/NACO; Richard, Jerôme, c. 1720-: Vatican Library)
L'humanité, ou Le tableau de l'indigence, triste drame, par un aveugle Tartare, 1761, online via Gallica, Jan. 23, 2014)
